I do not think that is anything new; I think that has always been true. It is because of this that have never understood why Members of the Conservative Party have always behaved so badly towards Service Ministers in both Labour and Liberal Administrations.
4.15 a.m.
In an amateurish sort of way I am a great student and a lover of the work of Lord Haldane, and think that beyond doubt he was one of the greatest Secretaries of State for War this country ever had. The treatment he received from the Tory Party can only be explained in psychological terms. The Tory Party rather resented his success because some of that party's back benchers thought that they ought to be doing the job. Although the Tory Party have dreams about Service Ministers, it is beyond dispute that they have always behaved badly towards Service Ministers in Liberal and—
I do not think that the hon. Gentleman is behaving kindly to this debate. He must confine himself to the Motion under discussion.

It is my opinion that the Tory Party behaved extraordinarily badly in producing Clause 1 in its original state. I am trying to explain why we have this terribly bad Clause, and why it has taken 13 hours of hard work to produce a much better Clause. I think it is frightfully important that hon. Members opposite should understand the psychological forces which work in their minds. In any case we had on Second Reading the much more horrifying statements of the Under-Secretary of State for War.
I shall be very grateful to my hon. Friend if he will speak a little louder because it is quite obvious that the hon. Lady the Member for Tynemouth cannot hear what is being said.
She is asleep.

If the hon. Lady is asleep, then let her sleep. I have no wish to disturb her.
I want to make what I think is a serious point. The Committee has to understand why this Bill, the first product of the Conservative administration, is such an obviously bad Bill, particularly as the present Prime Minister and other hon. Members opposite have repeatedly said—we had it all through the last Parliament and the one before that—that if there was one job which the Conservative Ministers could do best it was that of the Service Departments. In the Second Reading debate the Under-Secretary of State for War said: …but I say to hon. Members opposite: play the party game if you must in lesser matters, but leave the defence of this country out of it."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 22nd November, 1951: Vol. 494, c. 700.] I am sure that in making that statement the right hon. Gentleman really believed it. I do not dispute his sincerity. But what a confusion in understanding the tactics of his own party. Does not he realise that last February his own Prime Minister chose to play the party game and chose to bring defence into party politics? My right hon. Friend the then Prime Minister offered to bring him up to date about information for which he asked, but because he thought it would embarrass him he refused to accept the offer. Was not that party politics?
I really must ask the hon. Gentleman to confine his remarks to the Motion before the Committee and to try to keep in order.

I certainly do not want to trespass on your good nature, Sir Charles, and I do want to keep in order, but I think I am making a fair point when I say that this Clause is a very different one from what it was when we started. One must delve into the, reason for it, because we still have some way to go. I suppose that in the lifetime of this Parliament we shall have other Measures dealing with the Armed Forces, and it will save the time of the House if the Minister for Defence and the other Service Ministers really begin to understand that they can learn from my right hon. and hon. Friends. We have given them a lesson
during the last 13 hours. We have produced a workable scheme.
May I again go over some of the difficulties which the right hon. Gentleman has to face. He has decided first to register and then to enrol about 150,000 men. Clearly, that is going to make a demand on three sources where at present there is short supply. There is no doubt that we are short of trained instructors. They are short in the Regular Army, a point which the right hon. Gentleman has often made himself. Then there is the fact that nine or ten thousand National Service men are coming out of the Army every month and being absorbed into the Territorial Army. That raises administrative problems. The right hon. Gentleman has chosen this moment, when the supply of instructors is shortest, to add to the troubles of the Territorial Associations.
The second difficulty is that of equipment. I have no doubt that there is an ample supply of rifles and light automatics, but I am sure that we will want these men to be trained eventually in the use of more modern equipment. I am quite sure that I would be out of order if I said very much about the Colonial Army, but it is an extraordinary fact that hon. Gentlemen opposite have stressed over and over again the view, with which I whole-heartedly agree, that there was a need to do something to strengthen the colonial forces. But they have dropped all that. They have been forced to drop it if they are going to put their money on the Home Guard, because our money can only go to one place or the other.
The same applies to instructors. The third point is the question of accommodation. I thought that the right hon. Gentleman was a little disingenuous in his speech. He knows that the National Service men going into the Territorial units are going to make a demand upon every square inch of space available for the Territorial Army. He knows perfectly well that no make-shift arrangement will enable him to get over that difficulty; and he then suggests that halls should be available. Hon. Members have experience of the halls which are available in their constituencies. How many hon. Members could put their hands upon their heart and guarantee that for an hour each week—and more than that would be required—a public hall would
be available for use by the Home Guard? That is not true. It seems that the Home Guard will train in the open when the weather is fine, but goodness knows what is going to happen to them in the winter, which is the season when the right hon. Gentleman is going to begin his enrolment. Then here will be another 100,000 National Service men in the Territorial Army.
The right hon. Gentleman would have been wiser to have absorbed the statement made by my right hon. Friend the Member for Easington (Mr. Shinwell) and worked out a practical scheme based upon the Territorial Army Associations on the one hand; a scheme which also appointed Home Guard advisers to each of the Commands at home, so that one would have had a double chain of command down from the Army Council and the Director of the Territorial Army.
Had that been done, had the right hon. Gentleman decided to go slow about it I am sure a great number of the difficulties he is bound to face would have been avoided. But, of course, he is young and head-strong. I think, with great respect, he has forgotten all the rules he ought to know. His first job was to have made a competent appreciation, secondly to have prepared a plan, and thirdly to have tried to put the plan into operation. He has done a little of all three. He has got muddled up and he has not been helped by his Under-Secretary, quite clearly the most incompetent Minister of a most incompetent Administration.

As far as the concluding words of my hon. Friend the Member for Dudley (Mr. Wigg) are concerned, I am bound to say the Secretary of State for War really does seem to have been retiring from this Bill more and more as time goes on.
Mr. Head indicated dissent.

Well, the right hon. Gentleman seems to have been viewing it with increasing distaste—or perhaps that is his natural appearance. I hope he is as enthusiastic as when he started. I think we should discuss one important aspect of this Clause, especially as the Committee is in a mood to discuss things seriously. The right hon. Gentleman will realise that Clause 1 (3) deals with the granting of pensions and allowances in
respect of death and disablement such as may be prescribed by Orders or Regulations.
I regret very much that we have to raise this matter of detail at this stage, but the Secretary of State and you, Sir Charles, will realise that we have no other opportunity to raise it. The conditions under which these pensions and allowances will be granted will not be the subject of challenge or debate in the House. We are told we shall be able to ask questions and, if we are lucky in the Ballot, it may be we shall have an opportunity of a half-hour Adjournment. Unless the Leader of the House makes another concession—a phrase he is so fond of using—there can be no serious discussion of the level of allowances to be made to the disabled.
The only guidance we have had so far on this important matter is what the Secretary of State for War said on the Second Reading of the Bill. I do not complain he did not go further into it—it would have been hardly proper to expect him to spend more time on it. But he devoted only some seven or eight lines in Column 585 of the OFFICIAL REPORT to this important question of what disablement allowances are to be granted to the injured.
The right hon. Gentleman is putting the Committee in great difficulty if at the same time he goes on to say, "Unless you raise the matter on the Motion that the Clause stand part there is no other effective time at which you can raise an issue of this sort." I feel this will be an added argument I shall adduce at the right time for making these Orders and Regulations challengeable and discussable by the House. At the moment I am keeping on the right side of order by saying I must deal with this matter in some detail now.
I think the Committee, and the Home Guard, are entitled to know some more from the Secretary of State about his intentions in this matter. The guidance we have had so far is that the Minister will proceed on the general lines of allowances now granted and also that the allowances will be on a flat-rate. I am not an expert on industrial injuries or sickness benefits. There are other hon. Members far better informed on the subject than I am. But I am cer-
tain that there is a field of litigation into which the right hon. Gentleman will get unless he takes the Committee into his confidence and tells us what he proposes to do.
May I envisage an illustration which might quite well happen? A Home Guard decides to go to drill. He puts on his Home Guard arm-band. He carries his tin hat in his hand. He gets to the end of the road and meets a friend who says, "Do not go tonight—we have a darts match on; let us go into the pub." They go into the pub and he never gets to the Home Guard drill. Supposing on the way home the man is knocked down and injured. Is he on duty? The obvious layman's answer is, "No." Has he any intention to go on duty? We have the Attorney-General with us—no, he has gone. These Law Officers flit in and out. The Solicitor-General was in a moment ago and now he has gone. We have the benefit of neither at the moment, so we must do the best we can.
4.30 a.m.
Without continuing these illustrations in any wearisome detail, the Secretary of State will see that this question of the intention whether a man was or was not going on Home Guard duty is going to get him in serious difficulties. What does he mean to do about it? It would hardly be fair to expect the Committee to part with this Clause until we have some further explanation from him about the general lines he proposes to take. I hope that later on he will support me when I come to suggest that these Regulations and Orders should be discussable in the House.
I conclude by saying this: we have had a long time on this Clause, and the contributions we have made, although not always to the taste of hon. Gentlemen opposite, have been valuable. We have had to do the best we could because we have had precious little assistance from hon. Members opposite. It is a remarkable change. There is the hon. Member for Edinburgh, South (Sir W. Darling), who has so enlivened us in the past with his penetrating contributions. He has sat silent all through.

The hon. Gentleman has been away too much. I did intervene
in the debate. He must attend more closely.

I thought I might draw the hon. Gentleman by making a comment that was not strictly accurate. The hon. Gentleman knows perfectly well that he has made no substantial contribution to this debate. It is really no use hon. Gentlemen repenting at this late stage. The hon. and gallant Member for Portsmouth, West (Brigadier Clarke) has played a great part in our deliberations in the past, and I should have thought that on a Bill of this sort we should have had a lot of assistance from him.
Would the hon. Member suggest that the last two speeches from his side were really of any assistance to anybody?

That is my point; we have had to do the best we could because we have not had his help. With his assistance we might have made this a better Clause; but at least he will admit we have improved it substantially.
Then there is the hon. and gallant Member for Worthing (Brigadier Prior-Palmer), who has left the stricken field. On all previous matters concerned with these issues he has been a foremost protagonist. Today he has made one or two interventions and that is all the assistance we have had from him. There are a lot more. The hon. and gallant Member for East Perthshire (Colonel Gomme-Duncan), who has always assisted us previously, has not felt able to give us his guidance. There are many distinguished officers who sit on the benches opposite who have been singularly silent. The hon. and gallant Member for Ely (Major Legge-Bourke) has made a contribution. I do not wish to include him in this general condemnation.

Perhaps I may remind the hon. Gentleman about how wide the debate may be on the Clause stand part? Debate upon this question must be confined to the Clause as amended (or not amended), and must not extend to a discussion of the circumstances under which particular Amendments were made or to a review in detail of the proceedings on the Clause. That is what, I think, he is doing now.

I think that is a very fair point, and I shall leave it with all speed, having made most of the points I intended to make. I do feel it will be for the benefit to the Committee as a whole if we can hope, when we are discussing these Amendments, to get some elucidation of the rapid drafting. It would be a help to the whole Committee, and not only to my right hon. and hon. Friends who happen to have some particular knowledge. Then we should get along better and faster and have the help of some more of the expert knowledge of the Committee.
There is the question about giving of whole-time service. As it is drafted, this Bill provides that members shall not give whole-time service except during any period during which the platoon or other part of the Home Guard to which they belong is mustered, or during any part of such a period. The Secretary of State in a speech earlier today gave us to understand that it might happen that a very small section of the Home Guard would be mustered; that it might not be the county Home Guard, but only a part of it which would be called into being. We ought to have some indication of who is going to do this mustering of the Home Guard, up to what level it is he proposes to delegate this responsibility, and at what stage will the responsibility for apprehending an attack rest.
There is an Amendment down.

Clearly one does not wish to anticipate a further discussion that is coming along. This is what is in the Bill now and, before we part with it, we ought to have some explanation without anticipating what is coming later in relation to this particular matter. It will affect the lives of a great many people and we ought to know what these volunteers, who go into the Home Guard, are letting themselves in for. We have covered this Clause, but I will not say we have covered it exhaustively, because I do not think we have.

I, too, am very much concerned with regard to this Clause on the pensions and disablement allowances for members of the Home Guard. I hope my hon. Friend will not take it upon himself to say the debate is closed?
I am sure you will not delegate that authority to me, Sir Charles, and I think my hon. Friend will see that that is so.
I only wanted to clear any misunderstanding.

What I was intending to imply was that had we had a little more time between the Second Reading and this Committee stage, we would have been able to consider further Amendments. I feel very strongly that this Bill has been a hurried piece of drafting and that it could be substantially improved. I think the Secretary of State realises that. I know the sort of difficulties they get into. One gets around a committee of this sort and they ask what legislation are they going to find and who can get ready first. The Secretary of State for War is the chap who has had to carry the can.
The Bill has come along without a real digestion before it could get to the Committee. It is a pity. This is a further argument against the shortness of time between the Second Reading and the Committee stage and an argument for postponing the Report stage and the Bill further. We know there is no real emergency for it, and I trust that before we part with this Clause the Secretary of State will cover some of the matters which have been raised and which are all important issues and matters of substance. I hope we shall be able to satisfy ourselves that we have given this rather shoddy and slipshod Bill as reasonable and detailed a scrutiny as can be expected.

I must agree with the hon. Member for Cardiff, South-East (Mr. Callaghan) that we have spent a good time on the Clause. He mentioned 13 hours, but I think it is now more than that. I confess that we would have learnt more and discussed it more had more of the time been spent on the Clause and less on other extraneous matters which intervened. [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."]

On a point of order. I should like you to give a Ruling, Sir Charles, on the statement just made by the right hon. Gentleman that you have been allowing extraneous matters to intervene in the debate. Is not that a reflection upon the Chair?
I did not understand that. I thought that the right hon. Gentleman was criticising my accepting the Motion to report Progress.
Is it in order for a right hon. Gentleman to say that Members have been dealing mostly with extraneous matters? Is that not a reflection upon the Chair for allowing Members to be out of order?
I do not think that it is any slur on the Chair. Reporting Progress is certainly not part of the substance of the Clause.

Hon. Members opposite are just as clear—[HON. MEMBERS: "Withdraw."]—in their minds, except that it is getting very early in the morning, as I am that there were quite considerable periods of time—I am not criticising anybody for it; I am merely stating the fact —when we were not discussing the Bill Clause by Clause. That is all that I am stating. I make no complaint of that, and I make no criticism of the Chair. I state it as a fact. There is not an hon. Member in the Committee who can deny that. Hon. Members are making a fuss about nothing, and I think—
The right hon. Gentleman must not—
Order.
Order. The right hon. Gentleman had not given way.
I made a statement of fact.
It is an opinion.

It is a statement of fact. [HON. MEMBERS: "NO."] There were periods when we were not discussing the Clauses in the Bill. It will be for the benefit of the Committee if we get on now to some of the matters that have been raised by hon. Members. They are very touchy about my first remark, which was not offensive. [Interruption.] It was not ungracious, and I hope we can now get on.
Mr. Callaghan rose—

I have no intention to be awkward. We spent quite a lot of time on that point. I did not want to be con-
troversial. Now, we will turn to the matters relating to the Bill.
The first point was raised by the hon. Member for Malden (Mr. Driberg), who asked for an assurance, which I readily give to him, that the Home Guard will not be asked to take part in any compulsory church parades. The right hon. Member for Dundee, West (Mr. Strachey) expressed great puzzlement about why the line—I think his geography was subject to some excitement from the Committee—should be drawn running from north to south, from Flamborough Head to Selsey Bill, and why it should have been arranged for the east to have one establishment and the west to be on a nucleus of cadres basis.
4.45 a.m.
I did give some indication on the Second Reading that, in general, the first two duties of the Home Guard were guarding vulnerable points, aerodromes and kindred installations. Assistance in Civil Defence came next in priority. Of these two types of target, roughly speaking, aerodromes and that sort of target are mostly situated in open country. There are other targets.
I do not want to shelter behind the screen of security, but what I can tell the right hon. Gentleman is that the distribution of vulnerable points throughout the country and of the aerodrome type of target was very carefully assessed by the staffs of all three services. Those are the reasons which were explained, and I personally am convinced it is a logical and practical method of division between practical strength on the one hand and nuclear strength on the other.
I can also assure the right hon. Gentleman that so far as Civil Defence is concerned it is intended that units should give the maximum amount of help. He will appreciate that the majority of really serious targets—the big industrial towns —are in the areas where at present, for the kind of anti-parachute role that will be necessary, it is proposed that, by means of the cadres, they can be raised very rapidly in the event of attack.
The hon. and gallant Member for the Isle of Ely (Major H. Legge-Bourke) asked me about competition between the Home Guard and the W.L.A. I can assure him that in the initial stages of the Home Guard, as we envisage it with a limit of
150,000, the numbers of women enrolled will be very small indeed. There will be no question of these very limited numbers, mainly for telephone and kindred duties, interfering with agriculture or the W.L.A.
There is no W.L.A.
I thought the hon. and gallant Gentleman mentioned the W.L.A. He asked me about it. For all I know there is one in the Isle of Ely.
I said that when the Home Guard was being mustered, it might be possible that the W.L.A. would be revived.

The hon. Member for Fulham, East (Mr. M. Stewart) was anxious about the question of aliens. We propose to treat the Home Guard in exactly the same way as the Territorial Army and the Regular Army—that is to say aliens will only be allowed to enter the Force after special precautions have been taken.
The hon. Member for Aston (Mr. Wyatt) wanted to know for how long the Home Guard was going to be called up. A man joins for two years and he can extend that a year at a time. But I wish I could say for how long it would be. I wish anybody in the country could. We are calling this Force because there is at this moment great international tension. We are unfortunately in a period of creating extra preparedness in our defences. As soon as that tension disappears, and the need for this step is removed, we shall at once disband the Force, and no one will be more pleased than I when I can come to the House and say that will be done.
Can the right hon. Gentleman say whether after disbandment members of the Home Guard will be covered for reinstatement in civil employment?
I was assuming that disbanding had taken place after there had been no war.
The men might have been away for weeks, or months, and have lost their civilian jobs.

Unless there was a war they could not be mustered. In peacetime they could not have their civilian jobs seriously interfered with, and if they
saw any serious signs of that they could leave by giving a month's notice.
The hon. Member for Newton (Mr. Lee) mentioned useful service done by organisations within the factories. We are aware of them, and that is perhaps the most useful and quickest form of guarding vulnerable points when the Home Guard is expanded. We are now proposing to restrict the Force to a nucleus basis, and the question of recruiting these factory guards does not arise, but we have it in mind in the plans which would be prepared for expansion.
He also asked whether it would be wise that essential or key men should be prevented from volunteering. We did consider that. To do it through the Ministry of Labour is a fairly lengthy and complex affair. What we propose is that it shall be the task of the local commanding officers when registration takes place to see that they are not enrolling men who will not be available to them because they are in key industries. I think one can trust the commanding officers in that respect.
The hon. Member for Ayrshire, South (Mr. Emrys Hughes) mentioned the question of Northern Ireland. In the creation of any force one has to make some allowance for common sense. If there were two battalions in Scotland and one consists largely of Campbells and the other of Frasers one would not put them next door to each other. Where there are antagonisms of the kind the hon. Member depicted one does not start that sort of thing deliberately by posting or transfers.
I do not know whether the right hon. Gentleman has heard of the massacre of Glencoe. What I want is an assurance that the Irish in Scotland will not be sent to Northern Ireland.

What I want is to avoid a massacre, and I assure the hon. Member that the principle in this to to avoid massacres. This Clause has, as many hon. Gentlemen have said, been fully discussed. There have been many Amendments accepted from Members of the Opposition for which I am grateful, most grateful. An hon. Gentleman complained that my appearance suggested that I was not particularly enamoured
of the Bill. I can assure him it is not. My appearance was caused by the fact that the clock was going round and progress was not what was expected. The Bill started off by giving the broad outline. There have been Amendments, and I think it has been improved. I hope in the subsequent stages we can continue with that work at a timely rate.
Several hon. Members rose—
Mr. Shinwell.
On a point of order.
There can be no point of order about whom I call.
This is another point of order. I put several matters to the right hon. Gentleman which he has not answered.
That is not a point of order.
No, but it is a point of indignation anyway. We have a right to have our questions answered.
Mr. Shinwell.
Hon. Gentlemen opposite just sit there like dummies. I have a right to an answer.
Before we part with this Clause—[Interruption.]
I want the hon. Member for Brierley Hill (Mr. Simmons) to restrain himself.
Let the right hon. Gentleman play the game.

Before we part company with this Clause, which has occupied the time of the Committee for many hours, I should like to draw attention to what it contains.
Some doubts were expressed whether some of my hon. Friends were in order in dealing with certain items in this Clause. I shall confine myself to what is in the Clause. I draw attention in the first place to what is an undoubted fact which no hon. Gentleman could possibly dispute, and that is that the Clause as now amended, together with the assurances of the right hon. Gentleman about further improvements on the Report stage,
is vastly superior to the Clause that was originally presented. The right hon. Gentleman has been courteous enough to acknowledge the assistance.

Before my right hon. Friend leaves that point, can he address to the right hon. Gentleman the points which my hon. Friend the Member for Brierley Hill wanted answering and the questions I raised on subsection (4), otherwise we may have the Closure moved before these important points are dealt with?

Naturally, I heard the questions addressed by my hon. Friends. I understood some of the questions were addressed to the learned Attorney-General, who for some unaccountable reason has left—I see that he has reappeared, and is seated at the far end of the Treasury Bench. Let us keep within the rules of order at this time: I am very anxious not to transgress them.
In ordinary circumstances I would not appeal to the hon. and learned Gentleman to reply to the discussion, but it so happens that certain questions were addressed primarily for his edification because his mind has to be illuminated by the ideas held by some of my hon. Friends. He made no response whatever in spite of the offer of my hon. Friends on matters in which he is primarily interested. Now, he shakes his head. Is that what we call a response? If he is not careful, it will fall off altogether, and then where will he be? It is about time that we heard something from the Attorney-General.

If the right hon. Gentleman will allow me, it is only fair to the Attorney-General to say that he said to me, "Shall I reply to the hon. and learned Member for Hornchurch (Mr. Bing)?" I arranged that I would reply, but he is quite willing to reply.

If the right hon. Gentleman had not been too hasty, he would have learned that I was coming to precisely that point. My hon. Friends expected the Attorney-General to reply, but the right hon. Gentleman endeavoured to reply, but completely failed, at any rate on some of the points that had been raised. [Interruption.] There is still time. After all, it is only five o'clock, and we made a promise to the Leader of the House, who I see is still here, though, I
must say, looking somewhat sleepy and jaded; the right hon. and gallant Gentlemen does not agree, but his appearance belies it.
There is still time for the Attorney-General to address the Committee, and none would welcome a speech from the hon. and learned Gentleman more than myself, because I noticed—this is not altogether relevant, but it is interesting—during the recent election that he did make some rather vicious attacks on some of the right hon. Gentlemen on this side, and I should like to hear what he has got to say.
That attack now would be quite out of order.

Before we part with this Clause, I hope the Attorney-General will feel that the time has arrived for him to make an effective response to the appeals addressed to him.
I want to deal with what is in the Clause. Let it be noted, in the first place, that it was hon. Members on this side who made an appeal that the Clause be widened, in order to embrace the female sex. That thought never occurred to the right hon. Gentleman. What does that denote? Surely the connotation is that the right hon. Gentleman was in such a frenzied hurry to introduce this Bill that he did not give this Clause careful consideration. That is the first point.
The second point is on the subject of consultation. It was hon. Members on this side of the Committee who played a very modest part in making an appeal to the right hon. Gentleman. It was this side of the Committee from whence came this request that there should be satisfactory consultation between the right hon. Gentleman and his advisers and representative bodies outside. This also had never occurred to the right hon. Gentleman.
Then we come to the question of the use of the Home Guard in industrial disputes, and we discovered to our surprise, though not altogether to the surprise of some of my hon. Friends, that hon. Members opposite thought it was quite unnecessary to introduce anything into the Bill which safeguarded the Home Guard against their use in the case of industrial disputes. It never occurred to them. Thus we have assisted in improv-
ing this Clause until it is now almost beyond recognition.
Now I come to the point of real substance which is this. The right hon. Gentleman himself mentioned it, and since he mentioned it, and, apparently, did not transgress the Rules of Order I also can refer to it. What he said to the House in justification of this Clause, and, indeed, of the Bill itself, preceded his suggestion that at some time or other when the emergency and the tension as he described it had passed away this Force would be disbanded. But he declared that at this time of tension it was necessary to create this Force, and that is what this Clause provides for.
I should have thought that at a time of tension, particularly when it has been necessary—and I say this by way of illustration; I am not arguing the merits or the demerits of the position—to send large Forces to the Middle East and to consider the situation in Malaya, which has become very grave indeed, and also to respond to the demands that have been made by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation in respect of the defence of the West, in other words, to live up to our commitments in all parts of the world in order to safeguard British interests this was the last time in which to set about the creation of this Home Guard, which, at any rate for some time to come, cannot be an effective Force and cannot make any substantial contribution to the defence of this country.
In my view it is just a waste of time. I shall indicate how I think this came about out of the knowledge I have of this matter. Some time ago it was decided to create the post of the Commander-in-Chief. The post was created as a part-time post to begin with, but as a result of criticism and, indeed, of further consideration by those associated with me, it was decided to make it a permanent post, and General Dempsey, who was promoted to this post, conceived the notion that the Home Guard should be established very soon.
But that was not the view of the military experts. General Dempsey was alone in that respect. The military experts did not consider the time opportune for creating the Home Guard. [Interruption.] I do not know what the Leader of the House has said, but perhaps he will be a little more audible so
that I can gather what is in his mind? That evokes no response from him, so I must be left to guess what he is talking about.
I want to know from the Secretary of State for War, or from whoever is to reply, what it was that caused the change at this particular moment. Was it some military emergency, some increase in the tension? Was it because it was thought that we were reaching a state of apprehension regarding airborne or seaborne attack? Were these the reasons which persuaded the right hon. Gentleman to proceed with the creation of the Home Guard?
No, that is not my view. I knew of nothing when I was at the Ministry of Defence—[HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear.") Can anybody imagine anything cheaper than those silly jibes from hon. Members opposite? Since they have indulged in these jeers, I want to make this statement quite categorically and to ask them to bring the Minister of Defence here to deny what I say. When they bring him here, let him speak not in secret Session, but in public Session and deny, if he can, what I am about to say.
It is that when I left the Ministry of Defence after association with Service Chiefs, to whom I pay a well-deserved tribute for their co-operation and goodwill and their activities in assisting in building up the defence of this country, and after association with the political chiefs of the Service Departments, I left the Ministry of Defence in a condition for which I need not apologise to anyone. Let the present Minister of Defence deny that.
I am sure that what the right hon. Gentleman, says is true, but it does not arise on the Clause under discussion.

In your opinion the truth has been established, Sir Charles. I am satisfied that those were not the reasons why it was necessary to create a Home Guard at present. Perhaps I might preface what I am about to say with the remark that if the right hon. Gentleman, imagines that I bear him any malice I beg him to dismiss that from his mind. I say that sincerely. Why should I do so? After all, he is entrusted with a
most difficult task. I know the sort of difficulties which confront him, and no one need envy him in his present position, or envy anyone associated with the defence of the country. It is a most un-popular task.
But I do say to the right hon. Gentleman, that I believe the reason he produced this Bill was that the Government had to produce something. The Tory Party had been in labour, and after a period of gestation—a very short period, in the circumstances—it produced this squalling infant. Actually, it was not such a squalling infant, for there has been hardly a squall or squeal from hon. Members opposite in the course of our deliberations. It is a small, infantile affair, a mouse which ought never to have been produced. There is no military tension or emergency to justify the Bill. We know what is in this Clause now. It is an improved Clause. We are not completely satisfied. That is why my hon. Friends have made their comments and observations. It may be necessary to say something more about the subject when we come to the Third Reading.
I shall not detain the Committee for more than a moment or two—[Interruption.]—that is, if I am allowed to start. [An HON. MEMBER: "Detain the Committee? "] If you are not quiet I will.
On a point of order. Is it right for the hon. and learned Gentleman to threaten you, Sir Charles? Surely he has no right to threaten you in that way.

I apologise, Sir Charles, although I do not admit that I was correctly quoted. I want, if I may, to clear up a misunderstanding. Two legal questions were asked, and it was suggested that I should answer them. I endeavoured to, and did rise but the hon. Member for Cardiff, South-East (Mr. Callaghan) asserted his priority. I thought, therefore, that as I had offered to intervene and had not been allowed to do so, my assistance was not wanted.

I called the hon. Member for Cardiff, South-East (Mr. Callaghan), before I was aware that the right hon. and learned Gentleman rose. Otherwise, I would have called him. I beg his pardon; it was my fault.

That was the position. I should not like the Committee to think there had been any discourtesy on my part. I welcome the opportunity of dealing with the question raised by the hon. and learned Member for Hornchurch (Mr. Bing) on Clause 1 (4). He asked why that subsection was considered necessary. I am rather interested to be able to answer that question for a reason I believe that the hon. and learned Member already appreciates.
5.15 a.m.
During the last Parliament a Private Bill was passed which dealt with the common informer. Unfortunately, owing to the attitude adopted by the then Government it was necessary for the proposer of that Bill to remove from the Bill any reference to Parliamentary disqualification proceedings, and so it is still the law that Parliamentary disqualification proceedings can be put into operation by means of the common informer. It is the fact that the view is held that certain of the operations of a member of the Home Guard might very well render a Member of Parliament liable to proceedings by that very objectionable gentleman we tried to abolish with much good will and co-operation from all parties in the last Parliament—the common informer.
Therefore, I am glad to be able to say that the explanation of Clause 1 (4) is quite simple. It is inserted to safeguard a Member of the House of Commons from what might be a real danger of attack from the common informer.

Will the hon. and learned Gentleman deal with a further point? I appreciate what he said with regard to the common informer. It also would be within the power of the House of Commons to deal with a Member who was a Home Guard but for this Clause in the Bill. But will the right hon. and learned Gentleman consider the analogies
of those other offices which are really old-fashioned Home Guard offices and see, between now and the Report stage, whether we should include those?

If I did that the inquiries would not be completed by the time I hope the Report stage will be reached. Another matter with which I have been asked to deal related to aliens. The laws is that an alien cannot serve in the Forces unless special provision is made to that effect. I think it dates from the Act of Settlement, 1700.
There is a provision in Section 95 of the Army Act that a person who is, for the time being, an alien enemy may, in certain circumstances, be enlisted in the Regular Forces, and under the provisions of Regulation 2 of the Defence (Armed Forces) Regulations, 1939, provision was made for aliens serving in all the Forces. Therefore, unless special provision was made the position today would be that an alien would not be allowed to serve in the Home Guard. I understand that is the position today and I hope that answers the point raised.

Will the hon. and learned Gentleman deal with the point we have been trying to deal with for something like nine hours—that is whether "and" means "and" or "or" and whether it is proposed to put down an Amendment on the Report stage to clear that up? It raises the whole question of military law at the present time.
I think the Committee are prepared to come to a decision.
Mr. Buchan-Hepburn rose in his place, and claimed to move, "That the Question be now put."
Question put, "That the Question be now put."
The Committee divided: Ayes, 180; Noes, 124.

tr.td: Crookshank, Capt. Rt. Hon. H. F. C.
Buchan-Hepburn, Rt. Hon. P. G. T.

div.p: Question, "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill," put accordingly, and agreed to.

speech.p:
Sir Charles, it is now almost 5.30 a.m. and it is something like six, probably seven, hours since the Chair considered it appropriate to accept a Motion to report Progress and ask leave to sit again. I did take the opportunity of presenting a similar Motion to the Deputy-Chairman while you were absent but, in his discretion, he decided not to accept it on the ground that insufficient time had elapsed between the acceptance and the Division on the previous Motion.
5.30 a.m.
I see the Leader of the House is present and I should like to ask him, before I actually move my Motion, whether he would now consider it opportune to make a statement on the Government's intentions as regards the remainder of the Amendments. He may feel that the time has arrived to advise Members to go home, and I have no doubt that hon. Members on all sides of the Committee[HON. MEMBERS: "Speak for yourself."] —would welcome the opportunity. I should have thought that Members opposite, who have protested, should be the last to make a protest. I have been watching them very carefully, and they have been yawning their heads off. [HON. MEMBERS: "Dull speeches."] They now inform me that the reason for their yawning was the nature of the speeches made in the course of the discussions. [HON. MEMBERS: "Your speeches."]
It may be that one of the Members opposite, with great wisdom, informs the Committee that I would put anybody to sleep. I have occasionally put people to sleep, not necessarily by making speeches, but that was in the old times. I do not want to inflict any further speeches upon the hon. Member opposite. I should not like to put him to sleep at this time of morning. I suggest it would be far better for him to go home and go to bed, and to have a good rest before he reappears in the course of
the afternoon to take part in our deliberations.
Therefore, it would seem to me that that is the best thing we can do, in the interests of everybody concerned, including the Government and the Secretary of State for War, who has suddenly disappeared. Of course, we have the presence of the Under-Secretary, who, with unfailing courtesy, is always ready to address the Committee, and who, when he addresses the Committee, rises superior to partisanship. But in spite of his presence here, it would be wise if we departed from the scene, at any rate temporarily.
I do not know what is the mind of the Leader of the House. He is sitting there cogitating, reflecting upon the situation. I wonder if he would care to have a consultation with the Patronage Secretary, because he also is concerned about it and is, incidentally, looking a bit sickly himself. I wonder whether the two of them, sickening over with a pale cast of thought, would co-operate for a moment or two and then inform the Committee what are the intentions of the Government? As they are not ready to respond —[Interruption.] The Leader of the House says that he cannot interrupt me. That is somewhat unusual for the right hon. Gentleman, who was a past master in the art of interruption when he sat on this side of the Committee. However, other places, other manners—or was it "Other times, other manners"? The right hon. Gentleman can have it as he wishes.
I gather from what the Leader of the House said—that he did not want to interrupt me—that he would like to speak after I have sat down, in which case, perhaps, I had better sit down before moving the Motion. [HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear."] I should be very willing to sit down in order to hear what the right hon. Gentleman has to say, if that is his intention. In the circumstances, I shall not move my Motion at this stage, in the hope that the right hon. Gentleman will declare the
intentions of the Government. No? The right hon. Gentleman is not ready to declare the intentions of the Government, so I am left with no alternative than to move my Motion.
I beg to move, "That the Chairman do report Progress, and ask leave to sit again."
The Question is, "That I do report Progress and ask leave to sit again." Those of that opinion say "Aye"—
Sir Charles—
—on the contrary, "No." Clear the Lobby.
On a point of order. I rose to address you, Sir Charles, before you put the Question.
I am quite entitled to put the Motion forthwith, and I did so.
The Committee divided: Ayes, 122; Noes, 180.
Motion made, and Question proposed, "That the Clause stand part of the Bill."

The Committee is entitled to know what are the Government's intentions, what use they propose to make of this Clause, and how they propose to apply it—if that is their intention. There is no indication in the Clause of their intentions. We should also be assured on the point mentioned by the hon. Member for Enfield, West (Mr. Iain Macleod), during some earlier remarks of mine, about how far this Clause can be used to affect the lives and interests of persons living in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
He seemed to think that arrangements could be made by which a person could be sent from the United Kingdom to the Isle of Man. At that time we had the advantage of the presence of the Attorney-General, who nodded his head
in assent to my proposition that that was not the way in which the Clause could be used; that this Clause might apply to persons resident or domiciled in the Isle of Man, but could not be used to direct the lives or influence members of the Home Guard resident in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. I gather that the hon. and learned Gentleman still thinks that this is the proper interpretation of the Clause.
5.45 a.m.
The Isle of Man is for all practical purposes a self-governing community with a Parliament—the House of Keys and Tynwald—which claims to be even more ancient than this House. The people of the island are, as I know after having had six years of dealing with them, jealous of this independence, especially in all matters concerned with the liberty of the subject.
The Leader of the House, who was for some years Under-Secretary at the Home Office has no doubt had oppor-
tunities of realising that this is so. I think we are entitled to know whether this Clause has been inserted at the request of the Isle of Man, or whether it has been put in the Bill without their request, and what consultations or negotiations there have been between His Majesty's Government and the Government of the Isle of Man on this matter.
I know that the Home Secretary (Sir D. Maxwell Fyfe) is at Strasbourg. The Under-Secretary was in the Committee yesterday, but I have not seen him during recent hours. It may be that he has flitted in and out on his way to the Division Lobbies without my having seen him, but he has certainly not been in the House for some time. I think the Department responsible for making arrangements between His Majesty's Government and the Isle of Man ought to be represented when we are dealing with a Clause relating to the Isle of Man.
We ought to know whether the adaptations which may be specified in any order will introduce in such an order dealing with the Isle of Man considerations which are not to be found in any orders relating to Great Britain or Northern Ireland. Is it proposed that a person resident in the Isle of Man may by these orders be made liable for duty in Great Britain or Northern Ireland, or are the duties of Manxmen confined to the Isle of Man?
We heard earlier in the Debate, when the matter was raised by my hon. Friend the Member for Ayrshire, South (Mr. Emrys Hughes), something about the difficulty of sending some persons recruited in the Irish quarter of Glasgow into Northern Ireland. I know something of the jealousy that exists, and I can see some considerable difficulty if someone recruited in Douglas was sent to Blackpool, for the patriotism of these people, in regard to their own hotel and boarding-house accommodation, especially when compared with their competitors in Lancashire, is something to be seen and experienced before one can realise how intensely patriotic people can be on that subject.
This Clause is one about which I think the Committee ought to know whether it is put into the Bill as something that may
be necessary in the future, whether it has been asked for by the Isle of Man and whether effective consultations have taken place between H.M. Government and the authorities of the Isle of Man. We have recently had a General Election. Since then there has been a General Election in the Isle of Man, and in view of the peculiar constitution of the representative institutions in the Isle of Man I should have thought that it was very doubtful if, during the period between the Isle of Man General Election and the present time, there has been anybody who can effectively speak for the Isle of Man in any negotiations that may have taken place.
We occupied about 14 hours in considering the previous Clause, and while I would not like to suggest that an important Clasue of this nature should be disposed of in less time than we took to discuss Clause 1, I think that, on this occasion, we might get from the Under-Secretary, if he is to reply, some assurance on the point I have raised, so that we may feel assured that the legitimate feeling of independence in the Isle of Man has not been in any way outraged by the course of the proceedings on this Bill.

I join with my right hon. Friend the Member for South Shields (Mr. Ede) in suggesting that this Clause requires some further elucidation before we on this side of the Committee, at any rate, are prepared to accept it.
Although my right hon. Friend has addressed some very cogent questions to hon. and right hon. Gentlemen sitting on the Government Front Bench, I do not view the prospect of a satisfactory reply with very great optimism, noticing as I do that this Clause of the Bill has, apparently, been entrusted to the Under-Secretary to the War Office assisted, presumably, by the Solicitor-General. It appears that the Attorney-General has moved down the line somewhat, and that we are not to be favoured with his intervention in the discussion that has become necessary on this Clause.
In my view, this Clause is most ambiguous, because it may mean many things. It could mean, of course, that it is the intention of the Government that citizens residing in the Isle of Man shall be eligible to volunteer for the Home Guard,
and that may be one interpretation to be placed on the Clause. It may mean that any person residing in the Isle of Man or domiciled there may enlist in or join the Home Guard, and, in that way, render himself liable for service in some part of the United Kingdom other than the Isle of man—in Scotland, England, Northern Ireland or Wales. It may also mean, of course, that persons residing in any of the regions I have mentioned may find themselves sent to the Isle of Man for the purpose of discharging their Home Guard duties.
We do not want to create any ill-will between the United Kingdom and the Isle of Man, and that is why it is important that the Committee should receive some assurance from the Government Front Bench that there have been the closest possible consultations with such authorities in the Isle of Man as may be concerned or who have a right to be consulted in this matter.
As we are discussing the Isle of Man, and the effect that this Bill may have upon the people living there and their liability to serve outside the island, and the effect it may have of a person enlisting in England being sent to the Isle of Man, consideration is also needed as to whether a similar Clause or a similar provision should not be extended to the Channel Islands. The Channel Islands may well play an important part in the Home Guard defence.
We cannot discuss the Channel Islands on this Clause.

I hope that now I have mentioned the matter, the Under-Secretary of State for War may find it possible on the Report stage to introduce an Amendment which will cover that point.
This matter of the Isle of Man and its relationship to the Home Guard defence arrangements of this country should be fully explained. We are anxious to know whether or not there have been adequate consultations with the authorities in the Isle of Man, because we do not want to encourage or hostility between the legislative Assembly and the historic legislative Assembly which has operated with distinction in the Isle of Man for many centuries past.
In the last war we made use of the Isle of Man as a dumping ground for all kinds of undesirable people, and I do not know whether that found favour with the residents there. I happen to know that there are quite a number of people living there who are not very pleased at the use made of that island by the Government of this country during the war years. We do not want to exacerbate the ill-feeling, relics of which still persist in the island as a result of the way or the use that was made of the facilities there during the last war.
I very much hope that the reasonable and sensible questions that have been addressed to the Government by my right hon. Friend the Member for South Shields will receive the careful and courteous consideration that they deserve. As I said at the outset, I view the prospect of such a reply with qualified optimism, seeing who is in charge of this Clause at the present moment. But I do not despair of an adequate, sensible and courteous reply, to which this Committee is entitled in response to the questions put forward by hon. Members on this side of the Committee with due regard to the responsibilities which we as the Opposition have to discharge in ensuring that before it leaves us this Bill is adequate for its purpose.
The Bill has not been very carefully drafted, and the Clause we are now discussing is a further example of the ill-conceived, ill-drafted and ambiguous language in which this Measure has been thrown at the Committee. I ask Members opposite to believe me when I say that we are trying to make the best of a bad job.
6.0 a.m.
This Bill is unsatisfactory from many points of view, and not the least in regard to this Clause, in which, it may be that with the best of intentions, we are laying in store for ourselves a lot of trouble with the decent, law-abiding citizens of that little island standing between the Lancashire coast and Northern Ireland. In an atomic war the Isle of Man may occupy a position of great strategic importance.
There is another matter which ought not to be overlooked. If, for example, the main base of the United Kingdom is destroyed we might find that, if hon.
Members opposite are still in charge of the destiny of this country, we shall have to assemble in the Isle of Man and enjoy the hospitality of that island to carry on our deliberations, as the House of Commons of the United Kingdom.
For that reason we must be careful not to embark upon procedure likely to alienate the law-abiding people of that island. Perhaps the Secretary of State, who is now here, indicates by his arrival that this matter is of such importance that it cannot safely be entrusted to the Under-Secretary or the Solicitor-General. I take leave to suppose that the importance of this Clause has necessitated the return to the Committee of the Secretary of State for War who, I hope, will be able to supplement, and will probably need to supplement, such answers to the points which have been raised as have emanated from the Under-Secretary or from the Solicitor-General.

I am sure that it will be agreed that this Clause, consisting of only three short lines, shows scant courtesy to one of our oldest allies. We must hope that before this Bill leaves the Committee we shall get some indication of what is intended in regard to our relations with this tiny island.
The attitude of hon. Members opposite shows no regard for the Isle of Man. The moment that Clause 2 of this Bill comes up for discussion the Secretary of State for War departs. He has no interest in the Isle of Man. The Solicitor-General takes over from the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General is not interested in the Isle of Man, and the Solicitor-General is trundled up to answer any legal points which may arise.
A bad sign.

The Under-Secretary is left to handle this matter with the Solicitor-General. It is true that the Leader of the House remains. That is probably because he is too tired to move. It is true that we had no reply from him when we last moved to report Progress. We may hope that he will take the opportunity to reply when we move to report Progress again. We may hope, perhaps, that the Leader of the House will give some dignity to this discussion by indicating when we may expect to have the
Report stage, and also how far it is intended to proceed with this Bill this morning.
I should like to draw the attention of the Committee to the way this problem was handled in the more spacious days of 1907. We had a great regard for our ally in those days and I propose to inform the Committee of the way in which the problem was dealt with then. As we have emphasised on every possible occasion, this Bill should have been based upon this great structure created by Lord Haldane, who I may remind the hon. Member for Edinburgh, South (Sir W. Darling), since he suddenly seems to be evincing some interest in the debate, was Lord Chancellor three times.
Also a Scotsman.

Then I hope I shall have the support of the hon. Member in getting the Government Benches to say they prefer to put down an Amendment themselves to deal with this gallant ally of ours in the way in which Lord Haldane dealt with the Isle of Man instead of dealing with the island in the very scant way of this Bill.
Since the hon. Member has referred to Lord Haldane in such glowing terms, he might bear in mind that Lord Haldane was the first great Englishman to advise co-ordinating Ministers.

I am grateful to the hon. Member for reminding me that perhaps my tribute to Lord Haldane was as scant as Clause 2 of this Bill. He was undoubtedly the great administrator of the Army. We owe a great debt of gratitude to him. We may say that our success in two world wars was due to the groundwork for which he was responsible. It occurs to me that just as Lord Kitchener undid much of the good Lord Haldane had done, so the new Secretary of State for War, another professional soldier like Lord Kitchener, is rushing into the War Office and bringing in a Bill which is certainly unworthy of the occasion.
I commend him to look back at the mistakes made by that other professional soldier, Lord Kitchener, and then to seek true guidance from the great work done by Lord Haldane. If he pays greater
regard to Lord Haldane than he does to Lord Kitchener there is some hope that we may get some sound work of administration at the War Office.
I wanted to compare the two methods of treating the Isle of Man. This Bill says curtly, in an off-hand way: His Majesty may by Order in Council direct that this Act shall extend to the Isle of Man, subject however to such adaptations as may be specified in the Order. It is not mentioned what adaptations are necessary. There is no indication at all how the Government will treat the island. Let us turn from that curt, off-hand wording and see how the problem was dealt with in Section 40 (2) of the Territorial and Reserve Forces Act, 1907. It says: This Act shall apply to the Isle of Man as if it formed part of, and were included in the expression, the United Kingdom, subject to the following modifications:— And it is these modifications I recommend to the notice of the Under-Secretary of State for War before he replies: (a) The Isle of Man shall be deemed to be a separate county; In other words, we recognise the status of that island. We put it on all fours with Surrey, Middlesex or Lancashire or any other county in England. We recognise and establish the status of that island in that first paragraph: References to the Governor of the island shall be substituted for references to the lieutenant of a county.
The hon. Gentleman must direct his attention to what is in this Clause alone on the Motion which the Committee is discussing.

I suggest there is simply nothing in this Clause to discuss, so I must of necessity go outside to deal with what ought to be in it. We are now discussing the Motion, "That the Clause stand part of the Bill," and there are no Amendments.
There are no Amendments on it, but on this Motion we must keep to what is in the Clause.
Surely the hon. Gentleman is entitled to give reasons why the Clause should not stand part of the Bill.
He is entitled to give reasons but not to deal with something outside the Clause.

I understand my hon. Friend's argument is that the Clause should not stand part of the Bill because it does not contain provisions that appeared in another Act. Perhaps he did not put it clearly, and I was hoping that some of us might be able to put it in another way later.
I would certainly like to elicit from the Secretary of State the reasons for putting this Clause into the Bill in this particular form. That seems to me to be what my hon. Friend is seeking to do.
It would be in order to ask the Secretary of State why this clause is in the Bill.

I accept the rebuke of my hon. Friend the Member for Hornchurch (Mr. Bing), and I congratulate him on seeing more clearly than the occupants of the Front Bench opposite what I am driving at. I was trying to get the Secretary of State to appreciate that Clause 2 is unsatisfactory because it contains nothing. It is curt and abrupt, and it gives no indication of what our relationship with the island is to be.
I was going to suggest that in Clause 2 there should be some reference to regarding the Isle of Man as a county for the purpose of organisation in the Home Guard, and that there should be some reference to the status of the Governor of the island.
That is absolutely beyond the Clause.

If I have made those points clear and cannot develop them further, I propose to go on to references to the High Bailiff or two Justices of the Peace in substitution for references to summary court of jurisdiction.
That, I am afraid, is subject to the same objection as the hon. Member's previous point.

You see, Mr. Hopkin Morris, the difficulty we are in. The Clause contains nothing and we are extremely limited in making our proposals. If we are not able to discuss what ought to be in the Clause, I suggest that the Under-Secretary withdraw it entirely and undertake on Report stage to put down the kind of Clause we would like to see
in this Bill, namely, a Clause containing information of our relationship with the Isle of Man.
The hon. Gentleman is trying to get around the difficulty, but it still remains. We are still limited to this Clause.

This Clause provides for an Order in Council, and surely my hon. Friend is entitled to ask whether that Order will bring the administration of this Act in the Isle of Man into line with the Territorial and Reserve Forces Act. 1907.

He is also seeking to bring it into line with a great variety of other things. If he is seeking to elucidate information from the Secretary of State as to why this Clause is here, that is in order. But to suggest that a variety of other things that are not in this Clause should be included, however, is totally different, and is not in order.

In view of the fact the words contained in this Clause are subject to an Order, is not it in order for somebody to suggest the details he would like to see in that Order, if this Clause is to stand part of the Bill? It seems otherwise that one is dealing with something which is absolutely unintelligible because it does not represent a factual position. It only represents a hypothetical position in respect of an Order which may be made at some future time, the contents of the Order not being available when we are discussing it.

We are confronted here with a short but ambiguous Clause. It is difficult to find out what its meaning is. Is my hon. Friend not entitled to apply analogies and look back on other legislation for the purpose of defining what is the obscure meaning of this remarkable Clause?

I have just pointed out that if the hon. Member is seeking to elucidate information regarding any ambiguity in the Clause, that is in order. If he says that some other Clause should be substituted for it, that is out of order.

Is not the actual position that an hon. Member of this Committee is entitled to say that if certain things are to be in the Order he would be prepared to accept the Clause as it stands, but that if they are not to be in the Order he would not be. If one cannot do that, there is very little purpose in discussing the Clause at all.
The Clause is very limited, and the Order is not before the Committee.

Clause 2 has the word "adaptations" in it, and it speaks of "adaptations" in the Bill to apply to the Isle of Man. Are we, or are we not, entitled to discuss what the "adaptations" should be when applied to the Isle of Man? The Clause says: …subject however to such adaptations as may be specified in the Order. As "adaptations" of the whole of this Bill is mentioned in this Clause, are we not entitled to discuss what ought to be the "adaptations" to apply to the conditions of the Isle of Man?
It would not be in order here to discuss the "adaptations" specified in the Order.

What my hon. Friend is doing is to compare the present holder of the office with a very famous previous holder, Lord Haldane. How is one able to show one's feeling of dissatisfaction more categorically to certain Clauses of this Bill than to illustrate it by showing that this Clause falls short of a Clause included by a Secretary of State, with whom it is a compliment to compare the present Secretary of State unfavourably. I feel that this presentation by my hon. Friend was a little lengthy, but it was a tactful one. My hon. Friend was diplomatically pointing out the difference between the scant courtesy of the present holder of the office with the greater amplitude of his predecessor.
The hon. Gentleman may make reference to it, but he can not develop in detail what is not in the Clause.

How can one explain, without going through this in the broadest outline, the great difference between Lord Haldane's treatment of the Isle of Man in that previous famous passage, which
I am sure all of us knew before, with these three lines of the present Bill? I do not see how it can be shown how the three lines can be expanded without the use of a few words of detail.
The hon. Member may be in great difficulty, but that is another matter. The Clause is a three-line Clause, and a very limited, narrow Clause.

On a point of order. I speak as one who hopes to catch your eye, Mr. Hopkin Morris, on this exceedingly important Clause. We shall be having to ask questions as to the meaning of the word "adaptations." We do not know whether they are to be geographical, statistical, or in the form of Statutory Instruments; whether they are to exclude military law or to add more military law; whether they are to apply to people in the Isle of Man only or to people from this country who are serving in the Isle of Man, and so on. Really, this is a constitutional argument of the greatest possible importance.
That is a separate question. The hon. Member, as I understood him, was discussing a totally different Section of an Act.
No.

It is so long ago since I was speaking, Mr. Hopkin Morris, that I had better start again. This is a difficult point to develop, and with the interventions from my hon. Friends, for which I am grateful, and as a result of the Rulings you have given, I see more clearly now the line that I must pursue.
I was trying to support my right hon. Friend the Member for South Shields, who was asking what would be the administration that would implement this very scant Clause of just three lines. All that I was doing was to compare this treatment with the more ample treatment given by Lord Haldane in 1907. I appeal to the Under-Secretary, although under your Ruling, Mr. Hopkin Morris, which I readily obey, I am not allowed to proceed any further in that direction.
I hope that the Under-Secretary will take advantage, in the fastnesses of the War Office, of reading the excellent Territorial and Reserve Forces Act, 1907, and will see for himself—[Interruption.] I
was dealing with Section 40 (2), which lays down very amply the exact relationship that should exist in the Territorial Forces, as they were in those days, between this country and the Isle of Man. We would like to see the same provisions made in the Bill, so that for all time there will be placed in the statute, as the Bill will become, the relationship between this country and the Isle of Man in the administration of the Home Guard.
I am sure the Under-Secretary would agree that to put in the Act what is intended and what the relationship is to be, is a much more satisfactory way of legislating than merely to say, in a curt, off-hand kind of way: His Majesty may by Order in Council direct that this Act shall extend to the Isle of Man, subject however to such adaptations as may be specified in the Order. As my right hon. Friend has said, it took some 15 hours to deal with Clause 1. Had the Government had their way, I have not the slightest doubt that it would have been just as short as Clause 2. That would have meant that we should have had just as much difficulty in dealing with the points on Clause 1 as we are now experiencing on Clause 2.
I ask the Under-Secretary to explain, when he replies to this brief Debate, exactly what is to be in the Order which is to be adapted. We want him to tell us when the Order is to come into operation. When the Bill becomes an Act and is applied to this country, when the line has been drawn from Flamborough Head to Selsey Bill, and when the Home Guard has been brought into being east of that line and the cadres have been formed on the west of the line, what will be the position of the Isle of Man?
Will the Order have been brought out by that time? I can foresee the same kind of difficulties that were foreseen by my right hon. Friend. If the Isle of Man is to be brought within the scheme of this Bill and Manxmen are to be formed into a Home Guard, perhaps the Under-Secretary will tell us whether their duties are to be limited to looking after their own homes in the island or whether, if the Manxmen are mustered, they can be brought across the narrow channel in boats to deal with Irish who have mutinied in Liverpool.
I hope that we have succeeded in showing the Under-Secretary that we are
very disturbed by the brevity of this Clause and I hope that before we go much further we may have considerable enlightenment from the Under-Secretary about what is proposed in the employment of this extremely brief Clause, and what will be in the Order adapted for the particular needs of this island.
I hope it will be—

On a point of order. Are you, Mr. Hopkin Morris, calling the Under-Secretary now to conclude the Debate, because up to now we have had only one speech in support of the extremely important observations of my right hon. and hon. Friends. Is it intended to conclude the Debate?
No.

I hope it will be for the convenience of the Committee if I attempt to answer the questions which have been put. I might start with the questions put by at least two hon. and right hon. Gentlemen opposite as to what are the intentions, particularly in the direction of movement of the Home Guard from the Isle of Man to the mainland or vice versa. One of the fundamental principles of the Bill is that before mustering there is no intention of their living away from their homes.
That is not so in regard to the Isle of Man because, of course, these provisions can be altered or adapted by Order.

I am talking about the Bill as it is and the area which is already covered. It has been emphasized by my right hon. Friend that there is no intention that members of the Home Guard should be called upon to live away from their homes in times of peace. It has further been emphasized by him that the conception was that the muster would be a local affair. It cannot be imagined that, even when mustering, there will be any need to move or advantage in moving Scotsmen to Northern Ireland or Manx-men to the mainland or vice versa.
As I understand it mustering is to repel attack, and if there is or is expected an attack in Norfolk, is it really suggested that Nottingham, Derbyshire and other Home Guards will not be sent there?

I think the hon. and learned Gentleman must know that the Home Guard is not a striking mobile unit. It is for repelling attacks in the Home Guards' locality, and to move large bodies of Home Guards from different areas is not contemplated.
6.30 a.m.
This is a permissive Clause. It does not impose the Home Guard on the Isle of Man. Of course it is the intention that consultations should take place before it is made to apply to the Isle of Man, and to be satisfied that the people there want it, and on the sort of adaptations required. But to take those adaptations straight out of a 1907 Act would not be a feasible proposition in 1951. This Clause imposes no hardship on anybody. The adaptations or modifications required would be laid down by Order in Council after consultation with the Isle of Man. Finally, it is suggested that we should redraft the Clause. In our view the Clause is satisfactory as it stands.

The Committee has just listened to the most ineffective, useless and hopeless sort of answer ever made in debate. I should have thought I was giving expression to the views of hon. Members in all parts of the House if I expressed our gratitude to my right hon. Friend the Member for South Shields (Mr. Ede) for initiating what appears to be a discussion of first-class importance.
This is the House of Commons trying to legislate. We have had produced to us a Bill which gives no detail of any kind, no information about the underlying principles, and which leaves everything to delegated legislation. We listened to hon. Members opposite for six years about delegated legislation, and this is the Bill which above all others is left to that form of legislation. This Clause says that the Government can adapt the Clause, without giving the slightest indication of what that means.
The Isle of Man has enjoyed independence of government for many centuries. It is one of the British Isles, part of our common heritage; we value it in spite of its old right of independence. It is fantastic that we should seek to pass a Clause of this kind without as far as we know any consultations having taken place with the representatives of the Government of the Isle of Man, or the
trade unions or the representatives of organised industry. It is much more monstrous that the Under-Secretary should say so casually "That is not the concern of this busy Government at this time, we ask you to pass this Clause without knowing whether they want it, or will co-operate in it."
Most of these matters are matters of detail which seem to me to be of importance. We must have information about the nature of the adaptations which the right hon. Gentleman has in mind in introducing the Clause. Are they geographical? Is there to be a line drawn from Douglas to Ramsey, and is there to be mustering on one side but not on the other? Is some special standard of law to be provided for Manxmen who are Home Guards which is not applicable to Home Guards in the ordinary way? These are important matters which raise important constitutional problems.
During the last war there was centred in the Isle of Man a large internment camp. It was necessary to staff it with people from Britain and Northern Ireland. What is the position to be now? Will there be a Home Guard made up of Manxmen and of people from the mainland and will these two bodies be subject to separate laws? What is the contemplated variation in the law to be?
The Under-Secretary seemed to know little about the Bill or of the courtesy due to the House of Commons when an important discussion is taking place. He said quite casually "We do not think that when we muster the Home Guard it will be more than a local operation." If all that is true why pass the Bill at all? Is it really contemplated that there is to be an attack on the Isle of Man? Or is it the case that we will never have to muster the Home Guard, and that the Clause is nugatory and indicates the purpose of trimming up the different islands and that the Government have covered them all as far as they can. What foreign power is it contemplated will attempt to seize the Isle of Man and result in the mustering of the Home Guard there?
We must face this problem of delegated legislation, which seems to be of fundamental importance. In Clause 1 we are told that Orders in Council can be made that will virtually alter the law of the country. We were told by the Solicitor-
General, I think inaccurately, that martial law is to apply in peace-time to everyone enrolling in the Home Guard—[Interruption.] Well, military law, but I think the term I used was a better one because it was to apply to civilians. Is it to apply to the Isle of Man?
Answer.
Surely it is obvious to the hon. Gentleman that if it is decided to form a Home Guard in the Isle of Man then on those occasions on which it is mustered its members will be subject to military law.

The right hon. Gentleman should acquaint himself with what his hon. and learned Friend said. He has now said "If it is mustered." We were told that whenever it was on duty in peace-time it would be subject to military law. Is this contemplated for the Isle of Man? Surely we are entitled to know. Why is it necessary to have a special set of rules for the Isle of Man? Before these rules are made will there be consultations with the representative Government there or with the organised labour organisations?
Is no one prepared to answer? Or has no one thought of it? Is this Clause to act as a cover for lack of thought and is somebody to think of it later? Do the Government know?
